title: Deutsches Nationaltheater und Staatskapelle Weimar
text:
The (DNT) is a German theatre and musical organisation based in <a href="Weimar">Weimar</a>. It is a twin institution, consisting of the theatrical (German National Theatre, now solely based in Weimar) and the <a href="orchestra">symphony orchestra</a> known as the . It has a total of six stages across the city and also hosts touring orchestras and theatre companies, as well as making appearances in electronic media.
The Staatskapelle Weimar.
History.
The precursor ensemble of Staatskapelle Weimar dates from 1482, with the formation of a musical ensemble in service of the Weimar "<a href="F%C3%BCrst">Fürst</a>en" (Princes). In 1602, the ensemble attained resident status at the Weimar court, as the "Herzoglichen Hofkapelle" (<a href="Duke">Ducal</a> Court <a href="Musical%20ensemble">Ensemble</a>). Notable musicians in the early history of the Staatskapelle Weimar included <a href="Johann%20Hermann%20Schein">Johann Hermann Schein</a> (1615–1616) and <a href="Johann%20Sebastian%20Bach">Johann Sebastian Bach</a> (1705, 1708–1717), both of whom went on to the <a href="St.%20Thomas%20Church%2C%20Leipzig">St. Thomas Church, Leipzig</a>. Bach particularly worked as resident organist and "<a href="Kapellmeister">Kapellmeister</a>".
<a href="Johann%20Nepomuk%20Hummel">Johann Nepomuk Hummel</a> served as the ensemble's "Kapellmeister" from 1819 to 1837, on the appointment by the <a href="Grand%20Duchess%20Maria%20Pavlovna%20of%20Russia%20%281786%E2%80%931859%29">Grand Duchess Maria Pavlovna</a>. <a href="Franz%20Liszt">Franz Liszt</a> began his tenure as "Kapellmeister" in 1842, and championed the music of <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Richard Wagner</a>, <a href="Hector%20Berlioz">Hector Berlioz</a>, <a href="Peter%20Cornelius">Peter Cornelius</a>. Through this and his teaching activities, Liszt enhanced the prestige of Weimar as a musical hub, notably conducting the world premieres of Wagner's "<a href="Lohengrin%20%28opera%29">Lohengrin</a>" in 1850 and Cornelius's "<a href="Der%20Barbier%20von%20Bagdad">Der Barbier von Bagdad</a>" in 1858.
After Liszt left in 1858, he was succeeded by <a href="Eduard%20Lassen">Eduard Lassen</a> who remained as director until his retirement in 1895. Lassen conducted several world premieres during his tenure, including the first performance of <a href="Camille%20Saint-Sa%C3%ABns">Camille Saint-Saëns</a>'s "<a href="Samson%20and%20Delilah%20%28opera%29">Samson et Dalila</a>" in 1877. <a href="Richard%20Strauss">Richard Strauss</a> served as second "Kapellmeister" under Lassen from 1889 to 1894 and led the premieres of his own "<a href="Guntram%20%28opera%29">Guntram</a>" and <a href="Engelbert%20Humperdinck%20%28composer%29">Engelbert Humperdinck</a>'s "<a href="H%C3%A4nsel%20und%20Gretel%20%28opera%29">Hänsel und Gretel</a>".
<a href="Peter%20Raabe">Peter Raabe</a> became "Kapellmeister" in 1907. With the end of World War I and the dismantling of the <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a>, the ensemble was renamed the "Weimar Staatskapelle". <a href="Ernst%20Praetorius">Ernst Praetorius</a> directed concert and <a href="opera">opera</a> programming from 1924 to 1933. Because his wife was Jewish, Praetorius left the post after the <a href="Nazi%20Party">National Socialists</a> ascended to power in Germany in 1933. directed activities there during the Nazi regime.
After <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> and the end of the Nazi regime, <a href="Hermann%20Abendroth">Hermann Abendroth</a> became "Generalmusikdirektor" (GMD) and chief conductor of the ensemble, serving from 1945 to 1956. Successive GMD's of the ensemble have included <a href="Gerhard%20Pfl%C3%BCger">Gerhard Pflüger</a> (1957–1973), Lothar Seyfarth (1973–1979), <a href="Rolf%20Reuter">Rolf Reuter</a> (1979–1980), <a href="Peter%20G%C3%BClke">Peter Gülke</a> (1981–1982), Hans-Peter Frank (1988–1996), <a href="George%20Alexander%20Albrecht">George Alexander Albrecht</a> (1996–2002), <a href="Jac%20van%20Steen">Jac van Steen</a> (2002–2005) and <a href="Carl%20St.Clair">Carl St.Clair</a> (2005–2008). <a href="Oleg%20Caetani">Oleg Caetani</a> was principal guest conductor of the ensemble from 1984 to 1987. The ensemble was officially renamed the "Staatskapelle Weimar" in 1988.
In September 2009, the Swedish conductor <a href="Stefan%20Solyom">Stefan Solyom</a> became GMD of the ensemble, with an initial contract of five years. He concluded his Weimar tenure in July 2016. In July 2015, the ensemble announced the appointment of <a href="Kirill%20Karabits">Kirill Karabits</a> as its next GMD and chief conductor, effective with the 2016–2017 season, with an initial contract of three years. In June 2018, the company announced that Karabits is to conclude his tenure as its GMD in the summer of 2019, following an inability to reach terms on a contract negotiation for extending his tenure. In June 2020, the company announced the appointment of Dominik Beykirch as its new chief conductor, effective with the 2020–2021 season. Beykirch had previously served as "Zweite Kapellmeister" and "Erste Koordinierter Kapellmeister" with the company.
